children.text: We are going to combine the two Python programs into a single C program.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
Steps for the first program (File1):
   - We read an integer n (number of lines)
   - For each line, we read a character (either 'M' or 'F') and two integers a and b.
   - We have two arrays m and f of size 368 (indexed 0 to 367) initialized to 0.
   - For each line:
        If the character is 'M', then we do:
            m[a] += 2
            m[b] -= 2   (note: in the Python, b is increased by 1, so we subtract at b)
        Else (for 'F'):
            f[a] += 2
            f[b] -= 2

   - Then we do a prefix sum over m and f for the entire array (0..367).
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: - We then traverse the arrays (from 0 to 367) and at each index we compute min(m[i], f[i]) and track the maximum of these minima.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text:
Steps for the second program (File2):
   - We read a string S (from stdin, but note: the first program already read from stdin, so we must be cautious).
   - However, the two programs are meant to be run in sequence.
children.label: high_level_plan

   - Then we do a prefix sum over m and f for the entire array (0..367).
   - We then traverse the arrays (from 0 to 367) and at each index we compute min(m[i], f[i]) and track the maximum of these minima.

   Final code structure:

        #include <stdio.h>
        #include <string.h>
        #include <stdlib.h>

        int main() {
            char line[100];
            int n;
            fgets(line, 100, stdin);
            sscanf(line, "%d", &n);

            int m[368] = {0};
            int f[368] = {0};

            for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
                fgets(line, 100, stdin);
                char gender;
                int a, b;
                sscanf(line, " %c %d %d", &gender, &a, &b);
                b++;   // because the Python program does: b = int(b) + 1

                if (gender == 'M') {
                    if (a < 368) m[a] += 2;
                    if (b < 368) m[b] -= 2;
                } else if (gender == 'F') {
                    if (a < 368) f[a] += 2;
                    if (b < 368) f[b] -= 2;
                }
            }

            int current_m = 0, current_f = 0;
            int max_val = 0;
            for (int i = 0; i < 368; i++) {
                current_m += m[i];
                current_f += f[i];
                int min_val = current_m < current_f ? current_m : current_f;
                if (min_val > max_val) {
                    max_val = min_val;
                }
            }

            // Now read the string for the second program
            char S[1000];
            fgets(S, 1000, stdin);   // includes the newline

            // Frequency array for the string
            int freq[256] = {0};
            int len = strlen(S);
            // We iterate over the string until the newline? Actually, we have the whole string including the newline.
            for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
                unsigned char c = S[i];
                if (c == '\0') break;
                freq[c]++;
            }

            int distinct = 0;
            for (int i = 0; i < 256; i++) {
                if (freq[i] > 0) {
                    distinct++;
                }
            }

            char *result2 = "No";
            if (distinct == 2) {
                int flag = 1;
                for (int i = 0; i < 256; i++) {
                    if (freq[i] > 0 && freq[i] != 2) {
                        flag = 0;
                        break;
                    }
                }
                if (flag) {
                    result2 = "Yes";
                }
            }

            // Output both results at the end
            printf("%d\n", max_val);
            printf("%s\n", result2);

            return 0;
        }

   Note: the frequency array counts the newline as well. This matches the Python program.
